content.webTitle: Court of protection extends ban on naming woman in right-to-die case

fields.headline: Court of protection extends ban on naming woman in right-to-die case
fields.bodyText: A legal ban preventing identification of a 50-year-old mother who died after refusing lifesaving kidney treatment has been extended by the court of protection. The interim ruling was announced by Mr Justice Charles, vice-president of the court, who said that he “struggled” to think of any public interest in identifying the woman who is known only as “C”. “How is the public interest advanced by naming her and causing great distress?” he asked. Media organisations are challenging reporting restrictions imposed by the court at the request of her family. At issue is whether there is a public interest in disclosing the woman’s name, particularly after she was the subject of a frank and personally critical judgment, and whether preventing identification after death establishes a restrictive legal precedent. During the hearing, Charles questioned whether some photographs published by newspapers – in which her face was pixellated – had already breached the injunction against identifying her. The court, he added, would have to consider the implications of what would happen if there was an inquest into the woman’s death. He said the case was likely to have an impact on a pilot project planned by the court of protection aimed at making its proceedings more transparent. He reserved full judgment pending further submissions. Lawyers for the media, who are seeking to name the woman, are to provide written evidence explaining why it would be in the public interest to identify her. The court of protection deals with cases involving sick and vulnerable people who may not be able to take decisions. In the case of C, who did not wish to undergo dialysis, the court ruled that she had the mental capacity to decline medical care at King’s College hospital NHS foundation trust in London. The trust is now said to be “neutral” about whether the woman should be named. The original anonymised judgment, written by Mr Justice MacDonald, said C felt her life had “lost its ‘sparkle’” and she did not want to grow old. Richard Spearman QC, representing one of the woman’s three daughters, told the court of protection: “The family are very distressed by what has happened. [This family] had nothing to do with bringing these proceedings to court. “The effect of the application by the NHS trust was to put an enormous amount of private material into the public domain. They had to come to court. “The purpose of having open justice is not to write invasive stories; it’s not to lift pictures off Facebook pages and contact dozens of people who may have known this woman … It is difficult to identify what public interest is served by naming C. There has been considerable press coverage following the judgment.” Some reporting of the case so far, he added, was no more than “digging for dirt”. One reporter had approached an 80-year-old woman who had rented out property to a daughter several years ago, claiming that he intended to write a “memorial piece” about the mother. Spearman said the family felt under siege and snatched photographs had been taken. “There’s evidence of highly intrusive and unacceptable conduct. If the anonymisation was lifted in this case it would be significantly worse.” Solicitors from the law firm Bindmans, representing the woman’s daughter, have said the mother should remain anonymous in death to protect her relatives’ human rights to private and family life. The youngest daughter is aged 15. Lawyers for the Daily Mail, the Times, the Daily Telegraph and the Independent argue that any ban on identifying the woman after death is a significant interference with the right to freedom of expression and that evidence of potential harm to family members is “very thin”. The Guardian is not party to the claim. In written submissions to the court, Adam Wolanski, counsel for the media organisations, said that now the woman had died she had no rights under article 8 of the European convention of human rights, which guarantees respect for private and family life. “It’s clear that the child is aware of the publicity around the case ... There is a proper interest in the name of a person who dies being a matter of public record whether or not there is to be an inquest,” Wolanski said. “Judges and practitioners in the court of protection must be on their guard to ensure that their naturally protective instincts, developed through years of giving paramount consideration to the welfare of children and the best interests of vulnerable adults, do not lead them to underestimate the importance of [freedom of speech issues].” In a different case last year, another judge ruled that a bar on naming a Jehovah’s Witness who rejected blood transfusion or treatment with blood products could be lifted after she had died. However, Mr Justice Jackson said at the time that each case had to be considered on its individual merits, adding: “There is no good reason to conclude that the person’s death should lead automatically to all protection being lost.” The case continues.
